question: Why the Indus valley civilization is also known as the Harappa culture?
option1: The site of Harappa is six times larger than Mohenjo-Daro site
option2: The Indus valley civilization is considered the elementary/initial stage of the Vedic culture and Harappa is believed to be the same as Harappa mentioned in the Vedas
option3: Harappa was the first site to be excavated in the Indus valley
option4: The most important/significant evidence of the achievements of this civilization have been excavated from Harappa
answer: The most important/significant evidence of the achievements of this civilization have been excavated from Harappa
explanation: The Indus Valley civilization is also known as the Harappan civilization because the first site of the archaeological remains of the Indus Valley civilization was found at the modern site of Harappa, West Punjab, Pakistan.
